items.title: 5.1.2: requires sphinx_project module
items.body:
I cannot find `sphinx_project` module.
Is it some bub or I'm blind and by this I cannot find that module? :)

items.title: misspellings do not create an error
items.body:
The example on the [Running](https://sphinxcontrib-spelling.readthedocs.io/en/latest/run.html) documentation page shows that a misspelling will cause a make error. However, I’m not seeing that behavior. Instead, I get the following message and an 0 exit code.

```
Spelling checker messages written to /Users/gonsie/xxx/_build/output.txt
WARNING: Found 5 misspelled words
```

- sphinx-contrib.spelling version 5.1.1
- python version 3.7.7

items.title: `sphinxcontrib-spelling==5.1.0` + `Sphinx==3.1.0` explode under Python 3.7

Here's the log: https://github.com/cherrypy/cheroot/pull/291/checks?check_run_id=761123275#step:9:211.

I also have a green job "from before" that uses `sphinxcontrib-spelling==5.0.0` + `Sphinx==3.0.3`. I don't yet know what exactly causes this issue but I assume it's one of these. I must mention that this job is isolated to only run spelling and doesn't affect any other tests.

items.title: Invalid `python_requires` metadata stating the supported Python runtimes
items.body:
One of the factors `pip install` uses to identify if a given version is compatible with the current Python runtime is [`python_requires` entry](https://setuptools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/setuptools.html#new-and-changed-setup-keywords). It is strongly recommended to add something like `python_requires='>=3'` whenever you drop support for Python 2 (same stands for other versions, of course).

If it's not set, pip will assume that the given version is compatible with Python 2 and will select it for installation regardless of whether the code in the dist is compatible with it. So this leads to having broken installs for users.

I noticed that you removed Python 2 support via https://github.com/sphinx-contrib/spelling/pull/33 and https://github.com/sphinx-contrib/spelling/pull/47/files. And you removed the corresponding [Trove classifier entry](https://pypi.org/help/#trove-classifier) but that's not enough.
Trove-classifiers are only used as tags/categories for search on PyPI. pip doesn't take them into account at all.

This is also visible at https://pypi.org/project/sphinxcontrib-spelling/5.1.0/ — there's no "Python requires" entry in the left column. For example, if you look at https://pypi.org/project/CherryPy/18.6.0/, you'll see that it requires Python `>= 3.5`.

How to fix this
=============

1. Add `python_requires` to your `setup.cfg`.
2. Cut a new release and verify that "Python requires" is present (note: PyPI reads this metadata from wheels, not sdists, so make sure to have them uploaded too)
3. Modern pip + modern Warehouse (PyPI) now implement support for ["yanking" releases] ([PEP 592]) and you should use it: just hit the "Yank" button on PyPI for the "broken" releases. This will make sure sure that those will not get `pip install`ed by accident (unless users will specify the exact version in their pins, as in `== 5.1.0`). It's better than deleting because it keeps the release available on PyPI (it will just have a special label on the UI).

[PEP 592]: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0592/
["yanking" releases]: https://pypi.org/help/#yanked

items.title: Misspellings in autodoc doc strings can be hard to find
items.body:
https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/extensions/autodoc.html makes it easy to create documentation using the doc strings attached to items like modules/classes/functions. For instance, `index.rst` might contain:

```rst
.. automodule:: foo
   :members:
```

Misspellings in these doc strings are reported with:

- the filename being the file containing the `automodule` directive
- the line number (if it exists) being the line within the original doc string

This combination makes it very hard to identify the location of a misspelling in a large project. This is especially true if the misspelling appears many times elsewhere and so searching with `git grep` or similar has a lot of noise. For example:

- a misspelling like "tha" will appear as a substring of `that` a lot
- if a parameter name like `num_foos` is included without an appropriate role (like ``:code`num_foos` `` or ``` ``num_foos`` ```), a part like `num` might be flagged as a misspelling, and that `num` might appear in documentation and code a lot

Reproducer: https://github.com/huonw/sphinxcontrib-spelling-reproducer, particularly https://github.com/huonw/sphinxcontrib-spelling-reproducer/commit/ffae6cd5e67ad37e652a37f241a4b34dea5b919a

`docs/index.rst`:

```rst
...

.. automodule:: foo
   :members:

...
```

`foo/__init__.py`:

```python
def foo():
    """
    some words xyz more words
    """
def bar():
    """
    different text xyz other text
    """
```

Output of `make spelling` in the docs directory (after `pip install -r requirements.txt`):

```
$ make spelling
Running Sphinx v3.0.4
loading translations [en]... done
Initializing Spelling Checker
loading pickled environment... done
Ignoring wiki words
Ignoring acronyms
Ignoring Python builtins
Ignoring importable module names
Looking for custom word list in ~/projects/huonw/sphinx-spelling-reproducer/docs/spelling_wordlist.txt
building [mo]: targets for 0 po files that are out of date
building [spelling]: all documents
updating environment: 0 added, 0 changed, 0 removed
looking for now-outdated files... none found
preparing documents... done
index.rst:1:xyz:. [100%] index                                                                                                                                                                                  
index.rst:1:xyz:

Spelling checker messages written to ~/projects/huonw/sphinx-spelling-reproducer/docs/_build/spelling/output.txt
WARNING: Found 2 misspelled words
build succeeded, 1 warning.
```

Note that both badly spelled doc strings appeared as `index.rst:1`, and there's not much specific information to locate each one.

items.title: Warning when setting `spelling_word_list_filename` as a list
items.body:
Hello,

First of all thanks for this amazing tool!

We are in the process of updating our documentation and came across this feature introduced in 4.1.0 of specifying more than one dictionary setting `spelling_word_list_filename` as a list of files instead of as a string.

However, when running `$(SPHINXBUILD) -W -b spelling $(ALLSPHINXOPTS) $(BUILDDIR)/spelling`, we get a `WARNING: The config value 'spelling_word_list_filename' has type 'list', defaults to 'str'.`, which is causing the test to fail with:

```
Warning, treated as error:
The config value `spelling_word_list_filename' has type `list', defaults to `str'.
```

I can of course go around the issue by using just one file, but I'd like to avoid that if possible, since this second dictionary is just for words generated for an API reference, and I'd like to keep them separated from the normal dictionary.

Is there a way to suppress that warning? Or even better, is there a way to just don't spellcheck a set of directories? Actually, the latter would be the most beneficial, cause then I wouldn't need to build a second dictionary that just contains class and member names.

items.title: With a spelling_filter configuration is used, sphinx invalidates files on every build
items.body:
If i modify the  `spelling_filters` configuration value is set my `conf.py` file, like that:
```python
spelling_filters = [MentionFilter, URLFilter]
```

then Sphinx up-to-date check fails and recognizes all source files as needing a rebuild.

I noticed this message: 
    [config changed ('spelling_filters')] 8 added, 0 changed, 0 removed

...and then the regular sphinx percentage spinner kicks in for all my 8 rst documents.

To debug it, apart from the message above, i appended this function at the bottom of my `docs/sources/conf.py` file to listen to the `env-get-outdated` event:
```python
def setup(app: Sphinx):
    # for documenting the configurations of the new `graphtik` directive.
    def listen(*args):
        breakpoint()
        return []

    app.connect("env-get-outdated", listen)
```
and all 8 files are always in the 1st set `added` (as seen with the *pdb* command when the breapoint kicks in: `p args`).

### Versions
```
Sphinx                             3.0.0        
sphinx-autobuild                   0.7.1        
sphinx-rtd-theme                   0.4.3        
sphinxcontrib-applehelp            1.0.2        
sphinxcontrib-devhelp              1.0.2        
sphinxcontrib-htmlhelp             1.0.3        
sphinxcontrib-jsmath               1.0.1        
sphinxcontrib-qthelp               1.0.3        
sphinxcontrib-restbuilder          0.2          
sphinxcontrib-serializinghtml      1.1.4        
sphinxcontrib-spelling             4.3.0       
```

items.title: Please exit with non-zero status when misspellings are found
items.body:
The [documentation](https://sphinxcontrib-spelling.readthedocs.io/en/latest/run.html) makes it look as if the presence of misspellings will cause the command to exit with a non-zero status.  I have found that it does not (anymore?).
``` console
$ sphinx-build -M spelling . _build/
Running Sphinx v2.2.1
Initializing Spelling Checker
loading pickled environment... done
Ignoring wiki words
Ignoring acronyms
Ignoring Python builtins
Ignoring importable module names
Looking for custom word list in /docs/wordlist.txt
building [mo]: targets for 0 po files that are out of date
building [spelling]: all documents
updating environment: 0 added, 0 changed, 0 removed
looking for now-outdated files... none found
preparing documents... done
api.rst:36:implementor:] api                                                                
writing output... [100%] preface                                                            
Spelling checker messages written to /docs/_build/spelling/output.txt
WARNING: Found 1 misspelled words
build succeeded, 1 warning.
$ echo $?
0
```
This is inconvenient in CI setups and I work around this with an extra
``` sh
! test -s _build/spelling/output.txt
```
for the time being.

FTR, using sphinxcontrib-spelliing-4.3.0, Python 3.7

items.title: spelling directive doesn't work with parallel builds
items.body:
So I've tried adding a spelling directive with a list of words to the top of one RST file and it doesn't seem to work at all.
Any ideas on where do I start debugging?

I've looked into the source code and it seems it should do some logging but I don't see anything in the console output...

items.title: Does not work with Sphinx 2.0
items.body:
This extension works with Sphinx 1.8.5 (travis success buld log [here](https://travis-ci.org/grupy-sanca/curso-python/jobs/512286228)). But fails with Sphinx 2.0.0 (travis log [here](https://travis-ci.org/grupy-sanca/curso-python/jobs/512624976)).

```
Running Sphinx v2.0.0
loading translations [pt_BR]... done

Exception occurred:
  File "/home/h/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/sphinxcontrib/spelling/__init__.py", line 11, in setup
    app.info('Initializing Spelling Checker')
AttributeError: 'Sphinx' object has no attribute 'info'
The full traceback has been saved in /tmp/sphinx-err-yo9l19j4.log, if you want to report the issue to the developers.
Please also report this if it was a user error, so that a better error message can be provided next time.
A bug report can be filed in the tracker at <https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues>. Thanks!
make: *** [Makefile:20: html] Error 2
```

items.title: Dealing with contractions such as "didn't"
items.body:
At the moment, I'm having issues with this package correctly recognizing valid contractions such 
as ``doesn't`` or ``didn't`` - it will flag up ``doesn`` as being an incorrect spelling. What is the correct way to deal with this? Should I add ``doesn`` to the list of valid spellings, or is there a smarter way to fix this?

items.title: Documentation builds from old repo
items.body: The documentation at https://sphinxcontrib-spelling.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html has not been updated in a long time, looks like it still tracking the old repo on bitbucket

items.title: pyenchant is unmaintained: path forward?
items.body:
In case it's not known yet: It seems that *pyenchant*, the basis of this project, is not maintained anymore [1][2]. I'm not sure how a path forward might look like. Just wanted to let you know.

References:
[1] https://github.com/rfk/pyenchant/commit/4df35b72a685505546998fadfd0aeaa4cc530429
[2] https://rfk.id.au/blog/entry/archiving-open-source-projects/

items.title: Make it possible to use several dictionary files
items.body:
For example, when having a project that includes some docs using spelling in another project and one doesn't want to duplicate all words in the spelling file.

Would be nice to be able to say:

`spelling_word_list_filename=['spelling_wordlist.txt', 'other_wordlist.txt']`

items.title: Useful snipit of code for conf.py
items.body:
Thanks so much for sphinxcontrib.spelling!!

I have a snipt it of code you might find useful to offer here and wasn't sure best way to provide it.

The issue I had was using your spell checker in a situation where many developers are writing documentation and I don't want to burden all of them with having to install added dependencies to support it. And, that kinda sorta becomes necessary of the `.. spelling::` directive is used anywhere.

Here is what I did...

Added following code to `conf.py` to effectively *disable* `.. spelling::` directives by default.

```
#
# NO-OP the .. spelling:: directive for normal use
# spell_check.sh removes the call to app.add_directive
# before running sphinx-build.
#
def setup(app):
    app.add_directive('spelling', SpellingDirective)
    pass # Here so line above can be removed during spell check

from docutils.parsers.rst import Directive

class SpellingDirective(Directive):

    has_content = True

    def run(self):
        return []
```

Wrote a tiny shell script that copies `conf.py` to a temporary dir and then sed-modifies it to *remove* the `app.add_directive` and *add* the extension to the `extensions` variable...

```
#!/bin/sh

# Make a temporary dir for the adjusted conf.py file
tempfoo=$(basename $0)
TMPDIR=$(mktemp -d -t ${tempfoo}) || exit 1

#
# Copy conf.py and sed-replace the extensions variable
#
cat conf.py | sed \
    -e "s/^extensions[[:space:]]*=[[:space:]]*\[\(.*\)\]/extensions = [\1, 'sphinxcontrib.spelling']/" \
    -e "s/^    app.add_directive('spelling', SpellingDirective)//" \
    > ${TMPDIR}/conf.py

#
# Run Sphinx with spell-check builder
#
sphinx-build -c ${TMPDIR} -b spelling . _spelling
rm -rf ${TMPDIR}
```

This makes is possible to free everyone on team (and RTD server setup too) from *having* to install the additional libraries but still get the great spell checking your tool provides.

Thanks again!

items.title: Missing tag for 4.0.1
items.body: There's a 4.0.1 release, but no tag for it on github

items.title: AttributeError raised when misspellings are present (4.0.0)
items.body:
As of 4.0.0 (and with sphinx 1.6.4) the following exception is raised when a misspelling occurs:

```
Exception occurred:
  File "/path/to/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sphinxcontrib/spelling/builder.py", line 150, in finish
    self.warning('Found %d misspelled words' % self.misspelling_count)
AttributeError: 'SpellingBuilder' object has no attribute 'warning'
```

This commit (https://github.com/sphinx-contrib/spelling/commit/9f9768e48d51e7d3e0a5feebcf1402447c40fd95) appears to have introduced the issue.

items.title: With Sphinx 1.6.1+, contractions result in spelling errors
items.body:
Porting this over from: https://bitbucket.org/dhellmann/sphinxcontrib-spelling/issues/13/with-sphinx-161-contractions-result-in

The issue is that sphinx enables smartquotes; I'm not sure what the correct API is, but spelling should disable smartquotes in its builder.
